title: ICAC1
question: What will happen if you are caught cheating on the knowledge test?
optionA: You will not be allowed to take another test for 6 weeks.
optionB: You will never be allowed to take another test.
optionC: Nothing, there is no penalty.

title: ICAC2
question: What will happen if you offer a testing officer a bribe to pass your driving test?
optionA: Action will be taken against you. The penalties are severe and include fines and imprisonment.
optionB: Only the testing officer will be investigated.
optionC: Nothing, there is no penalty.

title: ICAC3
question: What will happen if a testing officer asks you for a bribe to pass your driving test and you give it to him or her?
optionA: Action will be taken against all involved. The penalties are severe and include fines and imprisonment.
optionB: Nothing, there is no penalty.
optionC: Only the testing officer will be investigated.

title: CG013
question: What is meant by this sign on or near a bridge?
optionA: Slow down and be prepared to give way to vehicles travelling in the opposite direction.
optionB: Stop at all times before crossing the bridge and only give way to pedestrians who may be crossing.
optionC: Do not overtake a vehicle travelling in the same direction.

title: CG017
question: Where there is parallel kerbside parking, are you allowed to double-park alongside a parked vehicle?
optionA: No, not at any time.
optionB: Yes, if delivering goods.
optionC: Yes, if not obstructing traffic.

title: CG030
question: You are driving at night with your headlights on high beam. When should you dip your headlights?
optionA: When within 200 metres of the vehicle ahead or an oncoming one.
optionB: When within 200 metres of an oncoming vehicle only.
optionC: Never, you are allowed to drive with your lights on high beam at all times.

title: CG031
question: You are driving in a 60 km/h zone, with only one lane for traffic in your direction. You see a bus ahead (with this sign displayed on the rear) signalling its intention to pull out from a bus stop, you should
optionA: Slow down, and give way to the bus as it has priority.
optionB: Sound your horn to stop the bus from pulling out.
optionC: Continue at your normal speed as the bus does not have priority.

title: CG043
question: If an oncoming vehicle crosses the centre line and is coming straight at you and you cannot stop, you should
optionA: Brake, look for room to the left, sound your horn and flash your lights.
optionB: Slow down and hope that the driver will turn away.
optionC: Drive onto the wrong side of the road and hope the other vehicle does not do the same.

title: CG044
question: If you are involved in an accident where your vehicle needs to be towed away and the Police does not attend the crash scene, you
optionA: Must report the accident to the Police Station nearest to where the accident happened within 24 hours.
optionB: Do not need to report the accident to the Police.
optionC: Only need to report the accident to the Police if someone was injured.

title: CG045
question: If your vehicle is involved in an accident (regardless of the damage), what details must you give, to the other driver(s), if asked?
optionA: You must let them see your licence, take details, and give the name and address of the vehicle's owner.
optionB: No details at all until you have contacted your insurance company.
optionC: Only your name and address details if a Policeman asks for them.

title: CG046
question: If a vehicle you are driving is involved in an accident and a person is injured, what must you do after stopping?
optionA: Render every assistance and take immediate steps to have an ambulance notified. Then call the Police.
optionB: Only call the Police if the accident also resulted in over $500 worth of property damage.
optionC: Report the accident to Police within seven days.

title: CG049
question: You should use your right-hand indicator when -
optionA: You intend to move to the right, at any time.
optionB: You intend to slow down.
optionC: You are about to stop.

title: CG052
question: When merging onto the freeway from the entrance, you should -
optionA: Look for a large enough break in the traffic and adjust your speed so as to fit into the traffic flow.
optionB: Sound your horn, turn on your indicator lights and move onto the freeway.
optionC: Stop and check the traffic behind you on the entrance.

title: CG053
question: If you see a sign indicating road repairs are going on, you should -
optionA: Slow down and watch for traffic controllers and instructions.
optionB: Stop immediately and wait for instructions.
optionC: Maintain the same speed.

title: CG055
question: You see a broken yellow line painted on the roadway adjacent to the kerb. What does it mean?
optionA: Clearway restrictions apply - you must not stop during the clearway hours.
optionB: You may at any time, park along this part of the road for 1 hour only.
optionC: Bicycle riders must ride along the yellow line.

title: CG056
question: If you see a horse and rider on the road what should you do?
optionA: Slow down and give them plenty of room.
optionB: Sound your horn to warn the rider.
optionC: Speed up to pass the horse.

title: CG090
question: You hear the siren of an ambulance approaching you from behind. You should -
optionA: Move into the left lane.
optionB: Slow down to the speed of other traffic.
optionC: Continue at the same speed.

title: CG094
question: Generally, if you hear the siren of an emergency vehicle you should
optionA: Pull over to the left until the emergency vehicle passes.
optionB: Immediately come to a stop.
optionC: Let the emergency vehicle pass and follow it closely behind.

title: CG102
question: You want to park your vehicle for a short time. It is night time. You should -
optionA: Pick a visible position or leave the parking or hazard lights on.
optionB: Park on the footpath.
optionC: Leave your headlights on high beam.

title: CG113
question: Looking at the diagrams, how far from the approach side of a bus stop or a railway crossing are you allowed to stand or park your vehicle?
optionA: At least 20 metres.
optionB: At least 50 metres.
optionC: At least 5 metres.

title: CG116
question: Bicycle and motorcycle riders have the same rights to use the road as other motor vehicle drivers. They are, however, more at risk in traffic because -
optionA: They are harder to see in traffic and do not have the same protection as many drivers.
optionB: They are careless and do not obey road rules.
optionC: They ride too fast and do not turn their lights on.

title: CG118
question: If you are driving towards a road works zone and a traffic controller displays a stop sign you must -
optionA: Stop your vehicle and follow the directions of the traffic controller.
optionB: Stop and then proceed if you think it is safe.
optionC: Slow down and continue through the road works zone.

title: CG119
question: If you are driving through a road work zone in the left hand lane and you see this sign you should -
optionA: Merge to the right and give way to other traffic.
optionB: Speed up to get in front of any cars traveling in the right hand lane.
optionC: Stop and wait for directions.

title: CG122
question: Do bicycle riders have the same rights and responsibilities as drivers and motorcycle riders?
optionA: Yes.
optionB: No, they must always ride on the footpath.
optionC: No, they must give way to cars at all times when riding on the road.

title: MG002
question: When is a motorcycle rider allowed to ride without an approved helmet?
optionA: Never.
optionB: When the rider has a medical certificate.
optionC: Only during daylight hours.

title: MG004
question: What equipment must be fitted to a motorcycle if pillion passengers are to be carried?
optionA: Separate footrests and a pillion seat.
optionB: Heavy duty shock absorbers.
optionC: An engine of more than 250ml capacity.

title: MG007
question: You need to stop quickly, you should use -
optionA: Both brakes together.
optionB: The front brake only.
optionC: The rear brake only.

title: MG008
question: To make a normal stop, you should use -
optionA: Both front and rear brakes.
optionB: The rear brake only.
optionC: The front brake only.

title: MG010
question: You are going to make a turn. When should you apply the brakes?
optionA: Before you start the turn.
optionB: As you come out of the turn.
optionC: While you are in the turn.

title: MG011
question: If you have to downshift for a turn, you should do it -
optionA: Before you start the turn.
optionB: Just as you begin the turn.
optionC: While you are in the turn.

title: MG012
question: If you wear regular spectacles while you ride -
optionA: You should also wear a face shield or visor.
optionB: You need no other eye protection.
optionC: You must not ride at night.

title: MG015
question: Every time before you ride you should check -
optionA: That the headlight and stop light are working.
optionB: Your fuel tap is not on ‘reserve’.
optionC: The expiry date of your licence.

title: MG016
question: What should you be able to see in each mirror fitted to your motorcycle?
optionA: About half of the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you.
optionB: The lane behind.
optionC: Your shoulder and the lane behind.

title: MG017
question: When you slow down for a stop, you should -
optionA: Downshift before stopping.
optionB: Downshift only if there is traffic ahead of you.
optionC: Downshift after stopping.

title: MG018
question: On a wet road how do you make an emergency stop?
optionA: Apply the front and rear brakes together.
optionB: Apply the rear brake only.
optionC: Apply the front brake only if the rear wheel begins to slide.

title: MG020
question: Where should you look when following a car?
optionA: Over or through the car you are following as well as watching its brake lights.
optionB: At the car's brake lights.
optionC: To the right-hand side of the car you are following.

title: MG021
question: In what part of the lane should you ride when being passed by on-coming vehicles?
optionA: The centre or left of your lane.
optionB: No special part of your lane.
optionC: As close to the centre line as possible.

title: MG023
question: A turn signal that keeps flashing after a turn is very likely to -
optionA: Confuse other drivers and cause them to turn into your path.
optionB: Damage the electrical system.
optionC: Keep other drivers from seeing your brake light.

title: MG026
question: You are being overtaken by a car on a two-laned road. In what part of the lane should you ride?
optionA: The centre or left of your lane.
optionB: No special part of your lane.
optionC: The far right of your lane.

title: MG027
question: If you have not ridden a particular motorcycle before, you should -
optionA: Allow extra stopping distance.
optionB: Use the rear brake only.
optionC: Not go faster than 30 km/h.

title: MG028
question: When riding on a wet road, what is usually the most slippery part?
optionA: The centre of the lane.
optionB: The right wheel track.
optionC: The left wheel track.

title: MG030
question: You are riding along on a sealed road when you see sand on the road ahead. What should you do?
optionA: Slow down because it takes longer to stop on a slippery road surface.
optionB: Stay at the same speed.
optionC: Increase your speed.

title: MG031
question: When riding over loose gravel or sand, you should -
optionA: Avoid sudden or quick movements.
optionB: Change up to a higher gear.
optionC: Slow down by using the front brake only.

title: MG032
question: When riding on a bumpy road -
optionA: Rise slightly on the footrests so that you can absorb the shock with your knees and elbows.
optionB: Keep your normal seating position.
optionC: Take your feet off the footpegs.

title: MG034
question: What is the first thing to do if you have a blowout?
optionA: Hold the hand grips tightly. Gradually close the throttle and let the motorcycle slow down.
optionB: Brake lightly on the wheel with the good tyre.
optionC: Turn quickly off the road.

title: MG035
question: At low speeds, if the rear tyre goes flat what is the first thing you will notice?
optionA: The rear of the motorcycle will tend to slide from side to side.
optionB: The steering will feel heavy.
optionC: Your brakes will not work.

title: MG036
question: At low speeds, if the front tyre goes flat what is the first thing you will notice?
optionA: The steering will feel heavy.
optionB: The motorcycle will tend to slide from side to side.
optionC: The motorcycle will lean heavily to one side.

title: MG037
question: To handle a high speed wobble, firmly grip the handlebars and -
optionA: Allow the motorcycle to slow down.
optionB: Increase your speed.
optionC: Quickly apply the brakes.

title: MG038
question: If your throttle sticks while in traffic, what is the first thing you should do?
optionA: Immediately squeeze the clutch lever, turn off the engine at the cutoff switch and apply the brakes.
optionB: Rotate the throttle back and forth several times.
optionC: Sound your horn to warn other vehicles.

title: MG040
question: When carrying a pillion passenger, the passenger should sit -
optionA: Behind and as close as possible to the rider.
optionB: Behind and as far from the rider as possible.
optionC: In front of and as close to the rider as possible.

title: MG041
question: In a turn you should tell a pillion passenger to -
optionA: Lean in the same direction as the rider.
optionB: Stay upright.
optionC: Lean in the opposite direction from the turn.

title: MG042
question: What should a pillion passenger do when you stop?
optionA: Keep both feet on the footpegs.
optionB: Place both feet on the ground.
optionC: Place the same foot on the ground as the rider.

title: MG043
question: A pillion passenger should hold on to -
optionA: The rider's waist, hips or passenger's handgrip.
optionB: The rider's arms.
optionC: The rider's helmet.

title: MG045
question: How old must you be to obtain a learner rider licence?
optionA: 16 years and 9 months of age.
optionB: 16 years of age.
optionC: 16 years and 3 months of age.

title: MG046
question: How long must you have held a rider's licence before carrying a pillion passenger?
optionA: 12 months.
optionB: 6 months.
optionC: 2 years.

title: MG047
question: If you are stopped by Police while riding a motorcycle on a road or road related area and you are not carrying your rider's licence you could expect to be
optionA: Given an on-the-spot fine or summonsed to Court by Police.
optionB: Given twelve hours to produce it at your local Police Station.
optionC: Told to go home and get it.

title: MG048
question: Police officers may check that you are correctly licensed when -
optionA: You are stopped for Random Breath Testing.
optionB: You stop to pay tolls.
optionC: Riding on a freeway or motorway.

title: MG050
question: Wearing the right protective clothing when riding can -
optionA: Greatly reduce injury in the event of a crash.
optionB: Make you very hot and reduce your ability to ride.
optionC: Make no difference to you when you ride.

title: MG051
question: When are you allowed to ride a motorcycle on roads in NSW without wearing a helmet?
optionA: Never.
optionB: When you have a doctor's certificate.
optionC: When the temperature reaches 32 degrees in summer.

title: MG052
question: What should be displayed upon an approved helmet?
optionA: An Australian Standards AS1698 sticker.
optionB: Bright stickers to make the helmet more visible to vehicle drivers.
optionC: A manufacturer's approval and checked by sticker.

title: MG053
question: To ensure a helmet is in good condition you should -
optionA: Only purchase a new one. Never buy a second hand helmet.
optionB: Only buy a helmet that someone else has tried out first.
optionC: Check to make sure it has not been dropped.

title: MG055
question: If you have a crash whilst wearing your helmet you should -
optionA: Replace it.
optionB: Check to make sure it is not damaged.
optionC: If it is scratched or chipped get it repainted.

title: MG056
question: If you find cracks or loose padding in your helmet you should -
optionA: Replace it.
optionB: Have it repaired by an authorised person.
optionC: Use high speed duct tape to hold it together as it is waterproof.

title: MG057
question: Wearing a helmet visor or goggles when riding will -
optionA: Protect your eyes from the wind, dust, rain, insects or stones thrown up by other vehicles.
optionB: Reduce your vision and should only be worn in the rain.
optionC: Not make much difference to your riding on a fine day when there is no wind.

title: MG058
question: The best type of footwear when riding are -
optionA: Boots which provide ankle protection.
optionB: Trainers or Joggers.
optionC: Steel toe capped boots.

title: MG059
question: Protective clothing should be -
optionA: Comfortable without being loose.
optionB: Very tight so they won't move if you fall off your bike.
optionC: Loose to allow air flow to keep you cool in summer.

title: MG060
question: Other protective options to wear when riding include -
optionA: Back protectors to protect your spine and kidney belts.
optionB: Nylon jacket and pants.
optionC: Light cotton shirt and pants.

title: MG061
question: When learning to ride you should -
optionA: Start in quiet streets that you know well.
optionB: Ride in groups so that you are protected from cars.
optionC: Gain experience in complex traffic situations to build your skills quickly.

title: MG062
question: Any passenger carried on a motorcycle (not in a sidecar) must -
optionA: Be eight years of age or older.
optionB: Be at least six years of age.
optionC: Be a holder of a rider licence.

title: MG063
question: Your ability to concentrate can be affected by -
optionA: Fatigue, alcohol, drugs and the clothing you wear.
optionB: The type of motorcycle you ride.
optionC: Whether you are familiar with the road you are riding on.

title: MG064
question: Correct riding posture -
optionA: Reduces fatigue and improves control.
optionB: Is whatever position you are most comfortable in.
optionC: Will make you more visible to other road users.

title: AD004
question: To reduce the effect of alcohol before driving or riding you should -
optionA: Wait. The time depends on how much you have drunk.
optionB: Drink black coffee.
optionC: Have a glass of water.

title: AD009
question: Before driving a motor vehicle or riding a motor cycle it is safest -
optionA: Not to drink any alcohol.
optionB: Drink 1 nip of spirits (30 ml or 1 oz).
optionC: Drink 1 middy (285 ml) of light (low alcohol) beer.

title: AD012
question: Is it an offence to refuse to take a POLICE breath test?
optionA: Yes, always.
optionB: No, if you say you haven't been drinking alcohol.
optionC: No, if you are a learner driver.

title: AD013
question: If you take medicine and then drink alcohol -
optionA: It can have a particularly bad effect on your driving ability.
optionB: The alcohol will have less effect than if taken alone.
optionC: Your ability to react to emergencies will improve.

title: AD015
question: Having 1 or 2 alcoholic drinks before driving -
optionA: Will affect your reactions and judgement.
optionB: Improves your driving ability.
optionC: Has no effect on your driving ability.

title: AD016
question: Even if you feel unaffected after drinking alcohol, you should -
optionA: Be aware that your abilities are decreased.
optionB: Drive, but avoid using freeways.
optionC: Spend more time than usual looking in the mirrors.

title: AD025
question: Alcohol is a depressant. This means -
optionA: It slows down how quickly your brain works.
optionB: It speeds your brain up so you can work better.
optionC: It makes you calm down and think more clearly.

title: AD026
question: After drinking alcohol you could -
optionA: Misjudge speed (your own and others).
optionB: Be able to drive the same as you normally can.
optionC: Be able to pay close attention to details in the traffic.

title: AD027
question: Which of the following statements relating to motorcyclists and bicycle riders is correct?
optionA: Alcohol affects their sense of balance.
optionB: Alcohol improves their concentration.
optionC: Alcohol improves their reflexes and judgement.

title: AD037
question: Consuming even small amounts of alcohol before riding may -
optionA: Affect your ability to control your motorcycle and make riding dangerous.
optionB: Help clear your mind by relaxing you.
optionC: Have no effect whatsoever on you.

title: AD038
question: What is the safest way to stay under the legal alcohol limit?
optionA: Not drinking any alcohol.
optionB: Buying a breathalyser (alcohol measuring instrument).
optionC: Exercising and drinking black coffee.

title: DR001
question: If you are taking any sort of medicine, you should -
optionA: Find out from your doctor or chemist whether the medicine or drug will affect your driving and act accordingly.
optionB: Only drive during the day after taking the medicine or drug.
optionC: Only drive a motor car not a heavy vehicle.

title: DR002
question: Before taking any drugs and then driving it is most important to -
optionA: Know what the effects of the drug are.
optionB: Plan to have some other person with you.
optionC: Have some food in your stomach.

title: DR004
question: If you have used illegal drugs you -
optionA: Must not drive.
optionB: May drive only in light traffic.
optionC: Should drink coffee before driving.

title: DR012
question: To ensure prescription drugs will not affect your ability to ride a motorcycle you should -
optionA: Tell your doctor you ride a motorcycle, check with your pharmacist and read the label on the drugs.
optionB: Not ride at all while taking any medication.
optionC: Not take the medication if you want to ride.

title: FD001
question: Under good conditions, when driving behind any vehicle, at any speed, you should -
optionA: Stay at least three seconds behind the vehicle in front of you.
optionB: Drive as close to the vehicle in front as possible.
optionC: Stay one second behind the vehicle in front of you.

title: FD002
question: When driving in wet weather, your vehicle will -
optionA: Take longer and further to stop, so slow down.
optionB: Stop in the same distance as on a dry road.
optionC: Handle better, so you can go faster.

title: FD003
question: At night, if an oncoming vehicle's headlights dazzle you, you should -
optionA: Slow down, until your eyes recover.
optionB: Watch the centre line of the road.
optionC: Close your eyes for a short time until they recover.

title: FD004
question: If you get sleepy while driving, it is best to -
optionA: Stop, rest, and change drivers if possible.
optionB: Turn on the radio very loud.
optionC: Turn on the air conditioning or open the windows.

title: FD005
question: In wet weather when it becomes hard for you to see, you should -
optionA: Turn on your headlights, slow down, and double your following distance behind the vehicle in front.
optionB: Turn your headlights on high beam.
optionC: Flash your headlights to warn other drivers.

title: FD006
question: If you are driving and it starts to rain, you should -
optionA: Slow down using the brake gently, since rain and oil may create a slippery surface.
optionB: Put your lights on high beam so you can see better.
optionC: Put your hazard warning lights on and increase your speed to avoid the rain.

title: FD007
question: When driving on a slippery wet road, for example, one covered in early morning dew, your vehicle will
optionA: Take longer and further to stop.
optionB: Be heavier to steer.
optionC: Be easier to steer and handle.

title: FD010
question: Why should you avoid heavy braking on a wet road?
optionA: Your wheels may skid and cause a loss of control.
optionB: If the wheels lock up your handbrake may not work.
optionC: You might wet pedestrians walking along the footpath.

title: FD011
question: At night you should -
optionA: Leave a longer gap behind the vehicle in front.
optionB: Use your hazard warning lights when overtaking another vehicle.
optionC: Drive closer to the vehicle in front so they can see you better.

title: FD013
question: When going on a long trip, out of the following which is the most important to do?
optionA: Get plenty of rest before starting out.
optionB: Make sure your horn is working.
optionC: Have a good meal before driving.

title: FD014
question: At night, when you approach an oncoming vehicle, you should -
optionA: Not look at its headlights, but keep left and watch the left of the road.
optionB: Carefully watch the vehicle by looking directly at its headlights.
optionC: Put your lights on high beam, to make your vehicle more easily seen.

title: FD039
question: To help prevent fatigue when riding you should -
optionA: Dress to protect yourself fully from wind, heat, cold and rain and not ride any longer than two hours at a time.
optionB: Stop and rest at least every four hours.
optionC: Ride in short sleeves shirt with no gloves to allow the wind to keep you awake.

title: FD040
question: What should you do if you have difficulty concentrating when riding?
optionA: Stop immediately and rest.
optionB: Ride without gloves and in a short sleeves shirt to allow the wind on your body to help you concentrate.
optionC: Constantly change your speed up and down to help you concentrate on what you are doing.

title: IN001
question: As you approach an intersection, you should check for traffic on your left and right -
optionA: At all times before entering the intersection.
optionB: Only when the traffic is heavy.
optionC: Only when you approach a stop sign.

title: IN002
question: There are no traffic signs or signals at an intersection. If you intend to drive through the intersection, you must give way to
optionA: Vehicles on your right.
optionB: Vehicles on your left only.
optionC: An oncoming vehicle about to turn right.

title: IN003
question: When making a right-hand turn at the intersection shown, you must give way to -
optionA: An oncoming vehicle going straight ahead or turning left and any vehicle on your right.
optionB: A vehicle approaching from your left and intending to turn right.
optionC: Only pedestrians.

title: IN004
question: If turning right at a T-intersection (as shown) must you give way to vehicles approaching from both the left and right?
optionA: Yes, whether they are turning or not.
optionB: No, only the vehicle on the right.
optionC: No, you have right of way.

title: IN005
question: If a STOP or GIVE WAY sign has been knocked down, for example, as the result of an accident, does the line marked across the road have any meaning?
optionA: Yes, it has the same meaning as the sign itself.
optionB: No, but you must give way if turning.
optionC: No, you only need to give way to the vehicle on your right.

title: IN006
question: If turning at an intersection are you required to give way to pedestrians?
optionA: Yes, a driver turning right or left must give way to pedestrians, if there is a danger of a collision
optionB: Yes, only if turning left.
optionC: Yes, only if turning right.

title: IN007
question: When you come to an intersection and the road beyond is choked with vehicles going in the same direction, what should you do?
optionA: Wait until there is room for you to completely cross the intersection.
optionB: Proceed if there is no traffic on your right.
optionC: Travel into the intersection and wait until traffic ahead moves.

title: IN008
question: Right-turns must be made from which lanes when travelling on a laned roadway?
optionA: The far right-hand lane or any other lane having an arrow pointing right.
optionB: The lane carrying the least amount of traffic.
optionC: The far left-hand lane.

title: IN010
question: In this diagram both vehicles O and P must pass through GIVE WAY signs before entering the intersection. Which vehicle goes first?
optionA: Vehicle P.
optionB: Vehicle O.
optionC: It depends on who moves first.

title: IN011
question: Vehicle O is at a STOP sign -
optionA: Vehicle O must give way to vehicles P, Q and R.
optionB: Vehicle O must give way only to vehicle R.
optionC: All vehicles must give way to vehicle O.

title: IN012
question: If both vehicles P and O in the diagram are turning right, which vehicle is in the best position to turn left into the street marked 'X'?
optionA: Vehicle O.
optionB: Vehicle P.
optionC: Neither vehicle.

title: IN013
question: The diagram shows a marked pedestrian crossing at an intersection. There is also a STOP sign at the intersection. You have already stopped for a pedestrian. Must you stop again at the STOP line?
optionA: Yes, at all times.
optionB: Yes, if there is traffic on your right only.
optionC: No, if the intersection is clear.

title: IN014
question: A GIVE WAY sign at an intersection means that you must -
optionA: Be ready to stop and give way to all other traffic if there is danger of a collision.
optionB: Stop completely at all times and have no right of way.
optionC: Slow down and only give way to traffic on your right.

title: IN016
question: Which vehicle in the diagram must give way?
optionA: Vehicle J.
optionB: Vehicle K.
optionC: Vehicle L.

title: IN018
question: You want to make a left turn. You must use your left-hand indicator -
optionA: At all times.
optionB: Only when there is traffic behind you.
optionC: Only when arrows are marked on the roadway.

title: IN019
question: At the T-intersection shown in the diagram which vehicle should give way?
optionA: Vehicle R.
optionB: Vehicle Q.
optionC: Whichever vehicle got there last.

title: IN020
question: You wish to make a right-hand turn from a ONE WAY STREET with no arrows marked on the roadway. You should position your vehicle
optionA: On the right-hand side of the street.
optionB: In the middle of the street.
optionC: On the left-hand side of the street.

title: IN023
question: When there are no arrows marked on the road, left turns must be made from -
optionA: The far left-hand side of the road.
optionB: The middle of the road.
optionC: Either side of the road.

title: IN026

optionA: Reduce the lean angle of the motorcycle so the tyres will grip better.
optionB: Sit towards the back of the motorcycle to give more grip to the rear wheel.
optionC: Lean as much as normal for the corner only be smoother on the throttle.

title: RS034
question: When riding a motorcycle at night you should -
optionA: Reduce speed even on roads you know well as you cannot see very far ahead at night.
optionB: Ride at all times with your headlight on high beam to give you better vision.
optionC: Ride as you normally would in daytime.

title: RS035
question: An important part of observation is -
optionA: Scanning.
optionB: Constantly performing head checks.
optionC: Keeping your chin up and look straight at all times.

title: RS036
question: The amount of time it take to react and respond to a sudden change in traffic is generally -
optionA: Three seconds.
optionB: Two seconds.
optionC: Less than a second.

title: RS037
question: A ‘low risk’ rider -
optionA: Has good observation, road positioning and hazard perception skills.
optionB: Is someone who does not take unnecessary risks.
optionC: Is able to react quickly to hazards because they have excellent reflexes.

title: RS038
question: You should check your mirrors -
optionA: Every few seconds so that you always know what is behind you.
optionB: Before you accelerate or brake so that you do not force people to change their speed.
optionC: Before every ride.

title: RS039
question: When riding towards the crest of a hill, it is best to -
optionA: Slow down and buffer from possible oncoming traffic.
optionB: Maintain a constant speed so that you do not confuse drivers behind you.
optionC: Change to a lower gear and apply more throttle.

title: RS040
question: Recommended additional protection for riders includes -
optionA: Wearing kidney belts and back protectors.
optionB: Wearing water-proof clothing.
optionC: Wearing sunglasses under your visor.

title: RS041
question: In addition to wearing a motorcycle helmet you should -
optionA: Ensure that you always wear motorcycle specific clothing.
optionB: Make sure that you also wear sunglasses for additional protection.
optionC: Wear a hair-net to help your helmet last longer.

title: RS042
question: When riding on a single lane road, a motorcycle rider -
optionA: Can legally use any part of the lane.
optionB: Must remain in the left of the lane at all times.
optionC: Must remain in the middle of the lane at all times.

title: RS043
question: When turning you should look -
optionA: In the direction you wish to go.
optionB: Down, so you can see the road immediately in front of you.
optionC: At traffic coming from behind.

title: RS044
question: When you see an oncoming vehicle you should -
optionA: Create a buffer between you and the other vehicle.
optionB: Always slow down.
optionC: Swerve to avoid it, while braking.

title: RS045
question: When taking a left curve you should -
optionA: Plan to finish in the left part of your lane.
optionB: Brake as late as possible to maintain your speed and balance.
optionC: Lean your motorcycle and apply the brakes throughout the corner.

title: SL007
question: Driving faster than the maximum speed limit is -
optionA: Never legally permitted.
optionB: Permitted only when passing another vehicle.
optionC: Only permitted when other vehicles are going faster than the speed limit.

title: SL015
question: A Shared Traffic Zone, where pedestrians and other road users can share the road safely has a speed limit of
optionA: 10 Km/h.
optionB: 20 Km/h.
optionC: 50 Km/h.

title: SL025
question: What could be the penalties for driving over the speed limit -
optionA: Fines, demerit points and possibly loss of licence.
optionB: Fines only.
optionC: A letter of warning and a small fine.

title: SL028
question: Where there are no speed limit signs, the speed limit is 100 km/h, unless -
optionA: There are street lights along the road.
optionB: The road you are driving on is gravel.
optionC: There's an emergency, which mean speed limits don't apply.

title: SL030
question: When you see this sign you must -
optionA: Not exceed 40 km/h and keep a special lookout for bicycle riders, pedestrians and children.
optionB: Only enter the street if you live in the local zone.
optionC: Drive at a speed less than 40 km/h if you are not a resident of the local zone.

title: SL031
question: This sign means you must-
optionA: Share this road with other people and vehicles and not exceed 10 km/h.
optionB: Drive at 10 km/h if there are pedestrians around.
optionC: Reduce your speed to what you think is safe but never below 10 km/h.

title: SL035
question: If you are driving along the highway and come across road works with a reduced speed zone, you must
optionA: Slow down to the new speed limit.
optionB: Drive through the road works zone as fast as you can to get past it.
optionC: Drive at the same speed as other vehicles.

title: TL001
question: You are facing traffic lights (as shown). What do they mean?
optionA: You may proceed only in the direction of the green arrow.
optionB: You may proceed only in the direction of the green arrow when the red light has changed to green.
optionC: You must give way to oncoming traffic.

title: TL002
question: At traffic lights what is meant when a red light appears?
optionA: Stop, wait behind the stop line until the lights change to green.
optionB: Stop, wait behind the stop line until the lights change to yellow.
optionC: Stop, make sure there is no traffic, then drive straight ahead.

title: TL003
question: What should you do when approaching traffic lights which change from green to yellow?
optionA: Stop at the stop line unless you are so close that sudden or sharp braking might cause an accident.
optionB: Speed up to clear the intersection before the lights change to red.
optionC: Stop, only if a red light camera is in use.

title: TL004
question: What may you do at an intersection with traffic lights at which this sign is displayed?
optionA: If the lights are red you must first stop, then you may turn left if it is safe to do so.
optionB: You should slow down and check if anyone is coming before turning left.
optionC: You may turn left only if a green arrow is shown.

title: TL005
question: Are you permitted to make a U-Turn at traffic lights?
optionA: No, unless there is a U-TURN PERMITTED sign at the intersection.
optionB: Yes, at all times.
optionC: Yes, if there is no danger of colliding with another vehicle.

title: TL006
question: These lights mean that you -
optionA: Can turn left, but not go straight ahead.
optionB: Can turn left or go straight ahead.
optionC: Can turn left only if a sign 'TURN LEFT AT ANY TIME WITH CARE' is displayed.

title: TL007
question: This light means, you -
optionA: Can go straight ahead, or turn left or turn right, if it is safe to do so.
optionB: Must stop and wait for the red light before proceeding.
optionC: Can make a U turn provided it is safe to do so.

title: TL008
question: It is 3 o'clock in the morning. You cannot see any other traffic. You want to turn right. You may
optionA: Not turn right while the arrow is red.
optionB: Turn right when you have waited one minute.
optionC: Turn right if it is safe to do so.

title: TL010
question: As you approach an intersection with traffic lights, the yellow light turns to red. You must -
optionA: Stop and wait for the green light.
optionB: Speed up to avoid traffic from the left and right.
optionC: Sound your horn and proceed through the red light.

title: TL011
question: You approach an intersection showing a red light and the sign shown. You wish to turn left. You must -
optionA: Stop and turn left only if it is safe.
optionB: Stop and wait for a green light.
optionC: Slow down and turn left or right if it is safe.

title: TL013
question: You are waiting at an intersection and the lights are red. The traffic lights change to green. You should
optionA: Check both sides of the intersection and then proceed.
optionB: Cross the intersection as quickly as possible.
optionC: Wait until the traffic behind you makes you move.

title: TL014
question: You want to turn right at an intersection and see this traffic light. You should -
optionA: Stay behind the stop line until the green arrow shows.
optionB: Move forward slowly.
optionC: Enter the intersection and wait for the green arrow.

title: TL015
question: You wish to turn left at this intersection. The traffic lights are red and you see this sign. You should -
optionA: Stop, then if you see it is safe turn left.
optionB: Stop until the light turns green.
optionC: Stop then go straight ahead.

title: TL016
question: You wish to turn left at this intersection and the traffic lights are green. What should you do?
optionA: Wait behind the stop line until there is room for you to enter the new road.
optionB: Move forward slowly, make the left turn and wait behind car A.
optionC: Enter the intersection and sound the horn.

title: TL017
question: As you approach a set of traffic lights at an intersection, they change from green to yellow (amber). You must
optionA: Stop before the lights, unless you are so close that sudden braking might cause an accident.
optionB: Drive through the intersection without accelerating.
optionC: Accelerate to clear the intersection before the lights change to red.

title: TL018
question: Temporary traffic lights at road works -
optionA: Must be obeyed.
optionB: Apply to road works vehicles only.
optionC: Are installed to warn motorists of construction works.

title: TL019
question: Where do you stop at temporary traffic lights?
optionA: At the ‘Stop here on red signal’ sign.
optionB: Where the lane ends.
optionC: After the traffic lights, but before the construction zone.

title: SI001
question: When you see this sign you should -
optionA: Not drive beyond the sign.

title: SI002

optionB: Turn left at next street.
optionC: Drive carefully, roundabout ahead.

optionA: All right lane traffic must turn right at the next intersection.
optionB: Right lane traffic may turn right or go straight ahead at the next intersection.
optionC: One way traffic ahead.

question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Traffic travels in each direction.

optionC: Double lane bridge ahead.

question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: You must not turn to the right.
optionB: You may turn to the right.
optionC: You must give way to traffic on your right.

question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: You must not turn to the left.

question: When you see this sign you
optionA: Must not stop your vehicle at the kerb during the times shown.

title: SI019
question: You are most likely to find this sign -
optionA: On the approach to a bridge which has room for only two vehicles, slow down and proceed with caution.

optionC: If there is a footbridge for pedestrians ahead.

title: SI020
question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Road may be slippery when wet, slow down and drive carefully.

optionC: Road under repair, drive carefully.

title: SI021
question: You are most likely to find this sign -
optionA: As you approach a winding road, slow down and drive with caution.

question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: A sharp depression in the road is ahead, be prepared, slow down.

optionC: Police station ahead.

title: SI024
question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Sharp bend to the right ahead, slow down and drive carefully.

title: SI025

optionA: Children may be crossing the road ahead, slow down and be prepared to make a safe stop.
optionB: There is an athletic field ahead.
optionC: Pedestrians are not allowed.

title: SI026
question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Crossroads ahead, reduce your speed and watch out for other traffic and pedestrians.
optionB: Hospital ahead, drive carefully.

optionA: Stop until red lights stop flashing then drive on if it is safe to do so.

optionC: You are approaching an intersection with traffic lights, be prepared to stop.

question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Slow down and beware of trucks entering from the side.

optionA: Slow down and look out for pedestrians crossing the road ahead.

optionC: Hospital ahead, slow down and proceed with caution.

question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Pedestrian crossing ahead, slow down and be prepared to stop.
optionB: Overhead footbridge for pedestrians ahead.
optionC: Joggers ahead, drive carefully.

title: SI033
question: You should expect this sign -
optionA: When a divided road ends and two way traffic is ahead.
optionB: If a one way street is ahead.
optionC: If a one lane bridge is ahead.

title: SI035
question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Workers ahead, slow down and be prepared to stop.
optionB: Children's playground ahead, slow down and be prepared to stop.

title: SI036

optionA: Watch out for bicycle riders along the roadway or when turning.
optionB: Bicycle riders not allowed on the roadway.
optionC: You are approaching a children's playground, slow down.

title: SI038
question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: If traffic lights are out of order or the amber light is flashing, you must stop and give way to traffic as if you are at an intersection with stop signs.
optionB: Stop, red light camera in operation.

title: SI039
question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Stop sign ahead, slow down and prepare to stop.
optionB: You are approaching a roundabout, prepare to give way.
optionC: One way traffic ahead.

title: SI040
question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Traffic controller ahead, slow down and be prepared to stop.
optionB: School children crossing the road ahead, prepare to stop.
optionC: Traffic lights out of order, Police on duty ahead.

title: SI041
question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Steep down-grade in the road ahead, slow down.
optionB: Road ahead slippery when wet, drive carefully.
optionC: Road under repair, slow down.

title: SI042
question: You should expect this sign, when -
optionA: A divided road is ahead, prepare for a change in traffic conditions.
optionB: A two lane bridge is ahead, slow down and drive carefully.

title: SI043

optionA: Railway level crossing with flashing signals ahead, slow down, drive carefully, and be prepared to stop.
optionB: Intersection ahead with traffic lights, prepare to stop.
optionC: Red light camera in use at traffic lights ahead.

title: SI045
question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Road narrows ahead, slow down and prepare for a change in traffic conditions.
optionB: Form one lane of traffic.
optionC: Merging traffic, give way to your right.

title: SI046
question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Vehicles are not allowed to stop at the kerb except in a medical emergency.
optionB: Vehicles must not stop at the kerb, except if picking up a passenger.

title: SI048

optionA: Vehicles carrying three or more people, and motorcycles may use this lane.
optionB: Motor cars carrying one passenger may use this lane.

optionA: Railway level crossing ahead, slow down and look out for trains, be prepared to stop.
optionB: Cattle or sheep crossing the road ahead, drive slowly.

optionA: Drive carefully and watch out for traffic entering from a side-road intersection ahead.

title: SI051
question: When you see this sign you must -
optionA: Stop at the stop line and give way to all traffic.
optionB: Stop at the stop line and give way to all traffic on your right only.

optionB: Stop and give way to all traffic even if the intersection is clear.

title: SI053

optionB: Slow down, then drive slowly over the crossing looking both ways for trains.

optionA: There may be animals on or near the road ahead, slow down and be prepared to stop to avoid collision.

title: SI064
question: What does this sign mean?
optionA: Only vehicles carrying a disable person and displaying a mobility parking authority may park in this area.
optionB: Motorcyclists may park in this area.
optionC: Vehicles may park in this area for up to ten minutes.
